results.title: The Land: the South Pembrokeshire coast
results.creator_credit: Granada International Productions, Julia Spark and Richard Guinea
results.brief_description: This film concentrates on the main features of the coastal landscape of the south Pembrokeshire coast of southwestern Wales, showing how the two different rock types: old red sandstone and carboniferous limestone, have reacted to the erosive forces of wind, wave and weather. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Land: South Lancashire coast
results.creator_credit: Granada International Productions, Julia Spark and Richard Guinea
results.brief_description: This film shows how man has adapted the south Lancashire coastline to meet the needs of work and recreation. The large industrial dockland complex of Liverpool shows how man has completely altered the coastal environment in order to satisfy his economic needs. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Land: Cumbrian Lake District
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International, Julia Spark and Richard Guinea
results.brief_description: This film shows the distinctive landform features which have been produced by Ice Age glaciation in the Lake District in England. Explanations are given of the processes which have produced such geographical features; the impact of humans through tourism is also looked at. Presented by Bill Grundy.

results.title: The Land: a new priority
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Roman Bittman and Roger Hart
results.brief_description: This documentary concerns the struggle of rural people in the Third World. The film takes us into the rural communities of Senegal, Kenya, Mauritius, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka, where foreign and local aid programs, combined with imaginative community projects, initiate small but significant changes. The brilliance of local dress, the traditional songs and dances, and the beautiful green images fail to mask the very real difficulty of finding a day’s food.

results.title: The Land that waited
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Alan Morris and Gil Brealey
results.brief_description: Using lithographs, engravings and water-colours, this film tells the story of the settlement of Australia, beginning with the arrival of Captain Phillip, and continuing with the toils and hardships of the early explorers and settlers on the alien, hostile continent. Winner of an Australian Film Award, gold award, for “its use of contemporary material in interpreting history”. Narrated by Nigel Lovell.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Alan Morris and Gil Brealey

results.title: The Land of Senegal
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television, Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais and Guy Sarthoulet
results.brief_description: Dakar, the capital city of the West African country of Senegal, is a magnet for thousands of farmers who flock into town and then cannot find work. The country has a one-crop economy - but peanuts are particularly vulnerable to market price fluctuations, so the Government of Senegal has asked for United Nations help in diversifying agriculture and training a new class of craftsmen and skilled cultivators.

results.title: The Land of Robert Burns
results.creator_credit: British Transport Films, Stewart McAllister and Joe Mendoza
results.brief_description: This short account of the poet’s life is set among contemporary scenes of the people of south-west Scotland as they grow from childhood to adulthood. A representative selection of his songs, sung by the Saltire singers, takes on fresh significance when heard against a background of the people and the countryside he knew and loved.

results.title: The Land of lots of time
results.brief_description: A fascinating trip from the Murray Gulf to the S.W. of N.S.W. with Graham Pizzey, well known naturalist. The emphasis is on how wildlife adapts to habitat.

results.title: The Land my mother = Walya ngamardiki
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Tom Manefield and David Roberts
results.brief_description: Inspired by Silas Roberts, a tribal elder of the Allawa clan who wrote to the 1976 Australian Government inquiry on uranium mining, this film gives an insight into the Aborigines’ attitude towards uranium mining. They tell of the myths and legends associated with the land and their sacred places, and why they object to the mining being carried out. Commentary by Bob Maza.

results.title: The Land must provide
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit, Douglas Gordon and Philip Owtram
results.brief_description: The major increases in food productin required to feed a rapidly increasing world population must come from raising crop yields on existing cultivated land, although much of the world’s land has become exhausted by endless use. This land can be made fertile again provided that there is sufficient moisture and by the introduction of the right balance of nutrients, such as that provided by chemical fertilisers.
